The case is just as bad in regard to the happiness of the gods For this can· not exist without virtue, and virtue without action is inconceivable. lf with the Epicureans we place happiness in sensual enjoyment, this is itself inconceivable in the case of such gods (ιιι, 112). There remain then only freedom from pain and the consciousness of eter- ' nal, never-ending comfort. But this is beset with difficulties3 for we cannot understand how with the continual stream of atoms flow- ing in upon them, and taking form again flowing forth from thern, the gods can have any certainty of never being annihilated. So then the Epicurean god is no more happy than he is immortal. When Epicurus speaks of piety and reverence for the gods, those are only phrases with no basis of truth3 for nobody cau feel rever· enee for such gods as his (113-116). And when he boasts of freeing men from superstition, that is all very easy if at the same time you substantially abolish the belief in the gods; the same boast may be made by those who deny the existence of any gods (117-119).
